reviewText: I am new to exercising, but I was given this tape for a good challenge. This is like nothing I've ever done before. It's weights while doing cardio and its really tough! It's a great challenge. I guarantee you will feel the muscles all over your body after doing this work out. I even felt it with out using weights the first few times doing the video. This is really  tough and I recommend it for someone who has exercised for at least a few months or is a beginner that can be patient with themselves as they are gaining strength and endurance.
Title: N/A

reviewerName: Amy R. Nix "Aspen74 - just another bibliophile"
reviewText: I rented this tape in 1996, and I bought it the next weekend.  I've used this tape as a regular part of my workouts for 3 years, and I'm finally buying a new one because my original is worn out!  I can't say enough good  things about it.  I've used it consistantly for 3 years, and it's still a  challenge.  That, in itself, is the beauty of the FIRM tapes.  If it starts  to get easy for you...just add weight.A word of caution:  This video is  MUCH harder than you'll expect it to be.  Start slow and don't use weights  at all until you've gone through the workout a couple of times.  Unless  you're in really good physical condition, you probably won't be able to do  the whole thing in the beginning.  It took me several months before I could  make it through the whole tape without skipping a few sections.There is  nothing in this world like a FIRM workout...and this tape is my very  favorite.  It was produced a long time ago, so the outfits and hairstyles  are kinda funny.  The music is way dorky, as well.  In spite of these  faults, the tape is so full of substance, that you'll easily be able to  overlook it's corny-ness.Susan Harris is genuinely an inspirational  instructor.  Some of her moves are a little unconventional, but they get  the job done - and done well.  She's energetic, but not annoying or bubbly.  She is really wonderful at reminding you to pay attention to form or  offering encouragement through the tough spots.  And...she's got a killer  set of legs and biceps that are just SO motivating.  You won't want to stop  until your arms look like Susan's!Obviously...I'm a believer.  I would  recommend this tape to beginners and advanced alike.  Everyone should start  somewhere, and the workout provided on this tape will be a challenge for  anyone.
summary: Once you do this workout...you'll never use anything else

reviewText: I love this workout video! I have used it in the past with great success. It was my introduction to the Firm and still one of my favorites. When I want to get a good workout with some serious hip and thigh work, I turn to this video. Because the aerobic portions are high impact I rotate this one with the other original 6 firm tapes. It's important to create muscle confusion and will give your body a balanced look. If you're serious about getting in great shape then you won't let the participant's dated looks bother you. The new firms are not very good and won't give you as good a workout as the old firms. If anyone tells you different, it's because they like the lighter work. Me I am a firm believer and new fitprime convert, you will be too when you do this tape.

reviewText: I have owned the original first six tapes since they were released around 1985 and they cost $40.00 a tape back then.  I was always about fitness and the most reliable way to maintain that fitness.  Each original firm tape offer variations of the workouts and the quickest way to get into shape.  No fitness tapes can compare to these workouts.  I am 55 years old and I still maintain a 34-25-36 body because I always go back to these workouts.  The Firm Total Body Aerobics with Susan Harris begins it all.  I guarantee that anyone who uses this tape or any of the other five tapes released after this one, will always get in shape and stay in shape.  Of course, I use other workouts but I eventually return to my Firm tapes even if a couple of years go by since I last used them.  This was the case in 2007.  I tore the miniscus in my knee and as a result I could not do anything until I had surgery.  After I had surgery and my knee was rehabilitated, I gained 52 pounds sitting and eating junk for about 4 months before the surgery. But I knew that I had to use my Firm tapes for the quickest results.  It took me six months to get my body back to its peak performance and shape.  The company that makes the Firm should release the original first six tapes on DVD since these are the bible of all The Firm workouts. There are The Firm Total Body Basics Aerobics with Susan Harris which is Volume I.  Volume II Total Body Low Imapact Aerobics with Janet Jones is next.  Volume III is Total Body Aerobic Interval Training with Sandahl Bergman which introduces using the bench for maximum lower body workouts.  Volume IV is Total Body Abs, Hips and Thighs Sculpting with LaReine Chabut.  Volume V Complete Aerobic Weight Training with Tracie Long.  And last but not least is the begining of the Firm Parts series Total Body Time Crunch Workout with Susan Harris and Kari Soremekun. I would tell any woman that if she wants the best body along with maximum amount of strong muscles, USE THE FIRM TAPES OR ANY OF THE FIRM WORKOUTS THAT ARE OUT THERE NOW, I just prefer the first original six tapes that I have owned since the 1980's.  I also guarantee that you will have the most admired guns (arms) around.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I first used this video 6 years ago, borrowing from a college roommate.  I liked it so much I bought my own, and since then have used it and other Firm tapes religiously.  This tape is awesome for all muscle groups--particularly the butt and arms!  I've enjoyed the adaptability of it, too--I started out barely handling 3 lb. weights, but I've been able to move up as my strength increases (and it still is!).  I never got the same results going to the gym.  Another plus is that it doesn't require any other equipment besides the weights (no steps or anything) and doesn't even require a whole lot of space, because there is no complicated footwork.  I like to alternate this workout with running, Tae Bo, or other cardio work, and then use the Firm Parts tapes.Plus, you can giggle at all the 80s music, clothes, makeup, hair, and Susan Harris's playboy voice (I do love her though!) :)  If these things would normally bother you, don't worry--the workout is so intense, they become the last things on your mind.  All that counts is that you feel absolutely stellar afterwards!

reviewText: This video actually was not my introduction to The Firm videos. I actually  tried V6 BEFORE I did this video. BIG MISTAKE!!! V6 actually turned me off  to The Firm videos for a couple of months and I continued to do my Kathy  Smith, Jane Fonda, and Body Electric workouts! Afterwards I decided to try  The Firm V1 because it does not require a lot of equipment. Anyway, my  whole body was aching after the first workout!!! The whole workout was a  challenge!!! I did this workout for several months before I did V2 and let  me tell you this. V2 does not even compare to V1 because it lacks the  intensity!
summary: this is a really great workout
Title: N/A

reviewText: This video has me spoiled, I am constantly searching for workout tapes on par with this one.  The 80's look doesn't bother me at all.  This workout is the only one that has actually slimmed my legs in a few months -- and I was only doing it 3-4 times per week.  The music may be hokey to some, but I think it creates a rhythm that makes the moves easy to follow. It is also very relaxing.This is an intense workout, but in some ways it's so easy to follow that I actually find myself enjoying it.  The first 2-3 times I tried it, I found myself overwhelmed, but I quickly became able to do it.  The only parts I skip are the jumping jacks, as they are too hard on my knees.  I also modify my lunges so that they aren't so deep, again because I want to protect my knees.I can't say enough about this tape and I think Susan Harris is an excellent instructor.  I have tried some of the more recent firm tapes.  They were all compilations of various instructors and I found them choppy and nerve-wracking.  This tape has a definite flow to it.  The camera work is pretty good, too.  I have tried tapes where the camera man would just focus on the instructor's face when she begins a new routine, so you can't even see watch she is doing.  This tape is easy to follow.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is the first of the FIRMS - the one that started it all, and I was anxious to try it out to see what started the whole FIRM following.After having done it several times, I have this to say:This is a workout for ADVANCED exercisers, or for those who definitely want to be advanced. Even if you thought you were advanced after months of kicking away to advanced taebo, this workout could still kick your butt. The floor work on this tape is some of the hardest out there. For amazing results, this video is one of the best. But what else can you expect from an hour long work-out with weights, cardio and extended floor work. They are not kidding about results in 10 workout hours - you WILL see them. That however does not mean you will lose 50 pounds in ten days - just that you will be on your way to loosing them faster than with just about any other exercising video out there, and you will start getting beautifully toned.However, before you grab this video at the nearest store there are a couple of things I would want to point out:1. This work-out was done in the mid 80s. If leotards, make-up and 80s music get in the way of your work-out you will not enjoy this. Also, if you currently do the more recent FIRMS and have not tried one of the original 6, you should know that the earlier videos are quite different from the later ones and you might not necessarily like the setting, music or the way the instructors cue.2. This, being an earlier work-out does not demonstrate the safest version of moves. As an example you do not squat to pick up or release your weights, and also in some of the lunges people's knees extend over their toes. If you already know about proper form you can do this work-out without following the bad example, but if not you may be better off picking up a tape where proper form is talked about and well demonstrated - some of the later FIRM tapes do a much better job at that.3. Finally, you need a set of dumbells for this workout (3,5, and 8lbs for women, 5,10,15 for men to start with) and ankle weights that are optional but recommended as you get stronger. As a beginner you should do the tape without weights and rest as needed, not doing the whole work-out your very first time. It will be practically impossible with that intensive leg work anyway.Keeping all that in mind you will enjoy this video if you want to do something serious for maximum results and have the time, equipment and determination necessary to succeed.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is one tough workout!  And it works!Susan Harris and The Firm will lead you through one of the toughest workouts of your life.  This workout hits all your major muscle groups using weights and has enough cardio to make all the cardio lovers happy.The moves are simple to follow but the tape is not boring.  Susan will keep you right on queue from start to finish.  Once you are done, you will know you've had a workout.  You will also see those visible results in 10 workouts, probably less.I started using the Firm Basics tapes and saw results in less than 10 workouts.  I've moved up to using some of the classic tapes and this is one of the hardest out of all the classics.  I continue to see results and improvement every time I do this tape.A warning to the out of shape:  This is not a beginner tape.  If you are out of shape try starting with one of the Firm Basics tapes and work up to it.  You'll be glad you did!A challenge to those who think they are in great shape:  Try this tape and see if you can keep up with Susan!
summary: Don't let the sweet lady on the cover fool you ...
Title: N/A

reviewText: I rented the Firm vols. 1,2 and 3 many years ago, but Vol. 1 (as it was  then titled) with Susan H. was the only one I instantly wanted to buy.  (Bought the others later!)  I've never been particularly athletic or  disciplined, but once I started using Firm tapes I've stuck wtih them--for  about 8 years now.  I think Vol. 1 is one of the best intros to their tapes  because it's the least "dancy" and easiest to follow, though, as  everyone says, it's not really a beginner's tape. (Their newer Tri-Trainers  Maximum Body Sculpting with Tracie Long  -- or it may be called All Weights  -- would also be a good intro to weight training.)  Anyway, buy the Susan  Harris tape and if you're a beginner, just do a FEW repetitions of each  exercise with no weights at first.  And don't feel frustrated if you have  to stop & catch your breath in between sections -- I STILL have to,  even after all these years!  But you really do get results with these tapes  very quickly, as everyone else has said. Try it and see if you don't get  hooked!
summary: Got me started on a permanent FIRM habit!
Title: N/A

reviewText: The great thing about the old Firm tapes and the new FitPrime workouts is that you can ALWAYS make them more challenging.  Even after you memorize the entire workout forwards and backwards, there is always the possibility of adding more weights to make it tough.  This particular workout includes an exhausting thirty minute floor routine that primarily works every muscle in your legs.  I saw results in less than ten workouts.  Some beginners may not like the layout at first, but remember do not use weights!  Just do the exercises to get familiar and work your way up.  The new Firm tapes pale in comparison, so do yourself a favor and go back to the beginning, you and your body will be thankful.

reviewText: This video may be 20 years old, but it stands the test of time.  If you can get past the dated clothes and music, you have in your hands an excellent workout that will challenge you for years to come.  The routine has a mix of cardio, weights and floor work.  In my opinion the floor work is the most challenging-- I hit muscle failure many times today.  Susan Harris, the instructor, frequently mentions going at your own pace, and I think this is the key.  Use weights if you can.  Do as many reps as you can.  This will not only give you goals to work toward but allow to you see progress over time.  If you're looking for a cardio-heavy, total low impact workout, this is not the tape for you.  However, if you can handle a little jogging in place and want to really challenge your muscles, give this one a try.  The Firm video series has flourished for 2 decades, and this video is one reason why!
summary: A Classic That Doesn't Let Up!

reviewText: Though not my favorite of the FIRM series (that would be the Total Body Workout #2), this is the one that got me hooked on the videos. reviewText: I remember as a teen in the mid to late eighties I would read from the new fitness magazine at the time, Shape, The Firm advertisements; they claimed that Jane Fonda's people wanted them to hide their mail because of the testimonials that their workouts were far more superior to Fonda's. They were so right! I picked this up this video when it was still around $... bucks, and it's worth every penny in gold. This video has the best hip and thigh exercises I have ever done.For people who are new to The Firm, and picked up these tapes when they were re-released under BMG management, they probably don't understand some of Susan's terminology in regard to certain exercises. The original tapes all contained 20 Questions About Fitness, which you can pick up at your local library if you can't or don't want to pay for it. It is an excellent informative section about the history of exercise, parts of the body, and explains the terminology of the exercises Susan performs on the tape.For some who can't stand the 80's feel I say get over it. Once you master the tape you can always put on music from the radio or CD player while you're working out. You will get results from this tape; it is a workout that has endured the test of the time. Even though The Firm has produced more up to date videos, the classic series (Vol. 1 -6) has the superior workouts. For those of you who want to know what ever happened to Susan Harris, she has two new exercise videos w/Anna Benson, who left The Firm a few years ago. Enjoy this workout!
summary: The one that gave birth to the Firm empire!

reviewerName: music lover "rigor mortis is my only hope for...
reviewText: I absolutely love the Firm.  I first found the firm in 1994 when I had gained about thirty pounds (over forty [stinks]!!) and was looking for an exercise video I could do at home because I didn't want to be seen in all my flabby glory at the gym.  This was the second firm tape I bought and is still one of my favorites eight years later.  Susan Harris resembles one of the Stepford wives (surely no one can be that perfect) but she leads you effectively through this workout which is absolute killer.  If you can walk up stairs and put on your pants the next day without discomfort, you must have come from the planet Krypton.  At the age of 48, I am now in great shape thanks to the Firm.  I am strong and flexible and wear a size 6.  I plan on doing the firm videos till I die.  This video will always be one of my favorites.  The hairstyles etc are a bit dated now (it was the 80's after all), but who cares when the end results are what we want in any era.  The best thing about this and all firm videos is that you can adjust them to your fitness level; start with no weights and gradually add weight as you get stronger.  You'll love the results.

reviewText: I find it truly astonishing that, even 20 years after I first bought this workout, it still gives me a fantastic total body workout.  And, no, it never gets easier :).  Other reviewers have put it very succinctly so what more can I say?  Everything about this video, from its phenomenal production techniques, exceptional lead, music (classical music that complements the workout and never intrudes) and the workout itself (a marvelous combination of cardio -- particularly SAFE cardio, considering that it was filmed in '86 or '87 -- and weights: exactly what exercise researchers are now coming to find the best) is absolutely classic and guaranteed to get your body in shape FAST. A fitness work of art.Fitness fads may come and go, but you can never go wrong with Body Sculpting Basics from the Firm.

reviewText: My mom and I have been doing Firm videos since the 90s...and this one will GET IT DONE!  I also have the Firm Wave system, and in my opinion, they just don't compare to the "originals".  Unlike the Wave participants, the ones in this video aren't cheesing like idiots...they are working hard (like you will be too!).  Not too hot about the running parts (I just don't like running in general).  But the leg work on the floor is KILLER!  I do agree with some other reviews that this video isn't real keen on good form, so I would recommend you learn good form before you try this.  I would also say to start with (really) light weights if it's your first time.  If you try and use the weight amounts that Susan says, you will pass out!  Yes, the video looks dated, along with the clothes, jewelry, music, etc., but if you are serious about getting fit and getting right you don't give a rat's behind about the way the jewelry and clothes look, get this!  You won't be sorry!  This is going to be my go-to video in my aim to get myself traffic-stopping right for spring and summer!  This is NOT for the true workout beginner (unless you go completely weightless through the entire workout), but for the intermediate/advanced enthusiast, THIS IS IT!  You WILL sweat, you WILL burn, you WILL cuss, you WILL (possibly) scream, but imagine a great body in exchange...
summary: Not for beginners, but will kick your butt if you can hang!

reviewText: This is one of the first Firm videos I ever bought, and while I don't do it often anymore, it is still a good workout and I like it for days I am in the mood for something different.  It is more aerobic weight training, which the Firm is known for.  The workout does move at a quick pace at times, therefore I use lighter weights than I normally use for heavier weight days.You will work all the major muscle groups, there are lots of squats and lunges, many of which are performed as compound movements, such as squats with front/side deltoid raises, plie squats with upright rows, lunges with bicep curls, etc.  You will also see upper body exercises performed on their own so you could "heavy up" for these if you choose to.  There is also a decent ab section at the end of the workout, along with some higher impact aerobics, some where light dumbells are used, which are referred to to as "Iron Aerobics".The segment that gets most mention amongst these reviews and rightly so is the killer floorwork that occurs after all the standing work.  It is brutal, I can lift a decent amount of weight for lower body work and consider myself to be pretty strong, but I am always tested by the floorwork and I fail miserably each time.  I cannot complete it without stopping and I use 2lb ankle weights, it's really tough.  How Susan Harris can hoist a 10lb dumbell on her leg and complete it is beyond me, she makes it look effortless.  You will hit every muscle in the leg during this section which contains table work for the hamstrings and behind, then when you have already had enough, you get to work the outer and inner thighs on each leg.  The outer thigh work I found to be the toughest by far.The workout was filmed in 1986, the music and outfits are dated, but it doesn't take away from the workout at all.  I actually like the music, most of it anyway and I think it suits the workout well.  Susan Harris does a great job, and she is working just as hard as you are with encouragement along the way. I think of all the Firm instructors past and present and can't imagine any other one leading this video.  She is incredibly strong and inspiring, and from what I read still looks great if not better almost 20 years later.  This workout still delivers a challenge after all these years.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was excited when I found out that I could get this on DVD. The music and the outfits may be outdated, but it's a really effective workout. Do this about twice a week, and alternate it with short intense cardio workouts like the paceexpress workouts, and you'll loose weight and tone up quickly.
summary: Old video, but the best one ever.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This was one of my first Firm purchases, many moons ago. It is considered a classic for good reason. The box description says that the workout requires "light weights", but you'll probably need a full range of weights from 3-20 lb. dumbbell sets to get the most out of this workout. You may even need to go higher eventually, if you are really advanced or a male. I would also suggest having a good pair of ankle weights (5 lbs. per side, preferably ones that allow you to go up or down by removing little weights in them), IF you have no joint problems or back issues. Susan also uses a pair of what she calls "toe weights"- they are used in the hands to make some of the standing aerobic work more effective, or around the ball of the foot during floorwork. 1 and 1/2 lb. wrist weights are what I found and used- they work great.It is quite dated now, but as an 1980's fan, I don't mind that. It doesn't take away from the workout's effectiveness or fun. The music is motivating. Susan Harris used to be known as "The Iron Goddess" in Firm circles, and she earned the title. Her experience shines through in this performance. She is strong, flexible, and has impeccable form. She obviously has a great rapport with her class, and taught this workout for months before taping it. So she really knows what you're thinking and feeling while you're working out. The class is gorgeous and have inspiring physiques, even if they are a little (obviously) competitive with each other.You start with a fairly long warm-up. I will say that this an 80's-style aerobics beginning, and you do need to watch your back and knees on some of these moves. That said, it is far safer than most of the workouts produced around the same time, by other manufacturers. After the warm-up, you do about 20 minutes of aerobic weight-training. Watch your form- it is easy to hurt your back if you don't perform this with precision (I speak from experience). Then it's on to a longgggggggg floor work segment (about 30 minutes). She includes push-ups, a ton of tablework (the best the Firm ever did, IMO), pec flies, bridge work, inner and outer thigh leg lifts, and ab work. It's tough and you will exhaust each muscle group- I have yet to read a post from any Firm user who said they breezed through this workout! Even the fittest amongst us would have to be challenged by this floor work. Susan has some of the best legs I've ever seen, and this workout does more for the thighs and butt than you could ever imagine. The floor work alone is worth purchasing the tape. Finally, you have a stretch. It's all challenging, but Susan keeps it moving well. It's about an hour long, and worth every minute spent.This was released on DVD a few years ago (though you have to do a little searching for it...), so if you don't mind an 80's look and feel to your workouts, go for it. A GREAT workout, when used with a little caution.
summary: Best floor work ever done in a Firm tape
Title: N/A

reviewText: When I first started working out with the Firm I was a bit nervious. Then shortly after I started working out my boyfriend say that my thighs and bootie were tighter! I highly recommened this video, BUT START OUT SLOWLY.
Title: N/A

reviewText: When The Firm Volumes 1-4 first came out, they cost a fortune--like $60-70 each, and people bought them at that price because there was nothing else like them on the market: carefully scripted, meticulously directed, and skillfully produced, but above all highly effective and enjoyable. I still don't think anything else comes close to this video in terms of quality and effectiveness, except for Volumes 3 and 4 (the latter of which is co-lead by Harris). I'm personally not crazy about volume 2--I find the instructor and the workout irritating, and later versions of The Firm just don't measure up to these classics; it's like they were afterthoughts struggling to remake the classic. Susan Harris' cueing and timing are impeccable, and she's encouraging and inspiring without being annoying in the slightest. While most of the outfits were tasteful for the production year and don't compare to some of the other gaudy attire in videos of the era, there's just enough hair spray and late 80s fashion kitsch to provide a nice diversion while you're working out :-) . I just started back doing this workout after about 7 years, and within two months I could see a remarkable difference in toning and weight loss. Simply the best workout ever in my opinion.
summary: If I could only own one fitness video, this would be IT.
Title: N/A
